channel.title: PHP Alternative?
channel.description:
So all I have been reading on here and I have heard from others that PHP is a horrible language to learn and people say that "They hope it dies out". So my question is should I continue to learn PHP or should I learn a better alternative language such as ASP or what other languages? Also why is it such a bad language? Im not too far in my process of learning PHP but I just want to know all of your opinions!!
Thanks ;D

item.title: PHP Alternative?
item.dc:creator: @Ashi Ashi
item.description:
@Ashi wrote:

[quote=“The Web Guy, post:42, topic:543612”][quote author=Ashi link=topic=662493.msg4428838#msg4428838 date=1402233062]
What makes you think people are moving onto NoSQL?
[/quote]

Yeah… I thought people still use SQL.[/quote]
They do still use SQL

Read full topic

What makes you think people are moving onto NoSQL?

item.title: PHP Alternative?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:40, topic:543612”][quote author=sinisoul link=topic=662493.msg4428617#msg4428617 date=1402087864]

Well most of you are saying stop with PHP and go with RoR, but then The Web Guy who I know happens to be a great web dev is telling me to stick with PHP

I just read this article that SilentCj commented http://www.leonardteo.com/2012/07/ruby-on-rails-vs-php-the-good-the-bad/ they say that RoR is such a better, and more powerful language but is very hard to learn for new programmers.

I am a quite a new programmer so Im not sure if I should take the Long easy route which is learning PHP then maybe another then go learn RoR

Or

Go the short route which is just starting on RoR and forgetting PHP.

If you want to go anywhere with website development you’re better going to Ruby. Especially Sinatra. Much more lightweight than RoR and isn’t as much of a pain in the ass IMO. If The Web Guy thinks you should stay with PHP then he is close minded and is being a burden to you. Learn Ruby, you’ll never turn back.

The industry is really quickly moving to NoSQL alternatives and RoR. I think knowing PHP would only be good so you could upgrade legacy systems.
[/quote]
What makes you think people are moving onto NoSQL?[/quote]

The 5+ interviews I’ve had where they each ask about my experience with Redis and Mongo. Now that doesn’t mean it’s entirely replacing SQL, but there are many adaptions to the newer NoSQL implementations. I should have phrased that as ‘becoming more common’.

Read full topic

item.title: PHP Alternative?
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“Ruby, post:38, topic:543612”][quote author=The Web Guy link=topic=662493.msg4428602#msg4428602 date=1402079884]

If The Web Guy thinks you should stay with PHP then he is close minded and is being a burden to you.

Lmfao, fudge off. You’re advocating for Ruby and telling him to do Ruby, I’m telling him to choose whatever he thinks is best for him. Tell me how I’m close minded and a burden, and you’re not?

You:

If you want to go anywhere with website development you’re better going to Ruby.

Me:

Do what you think is best, they both seem to do similar things.

[/quote]

You are not worthy of a reply. Peasant.[/quote]

You have no response.
You called me a name from the 15th century.
I’m so hurt.

Read full topic

item.title: PHP Alternative?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“The Web Guy, post:34, topic:543612”][quote author=Ruby link=topic=662493.msg4428568#msg4428568 date=1402050098]
If The Web Guy thinks you should stay with PHP then he is close minded and is being a burden to you.
[/quote]

Lmfao, fudge off. You’re advocating for Ruby and telling him to do Ruby, I’m telling him to choose whatever he thinks is best for him. Tell me how I’m close minded and a burden, and you’re not?

You:

If you want to go anywhere with website development you’re better going to Ruby.

Me:

[quote author=The Web Guy link=topic=662493.msg4428508#msg4428508 date=1402011939]
Do what you think is best, they both seem to do similar things.
[/quote][/quote]Well you’re implying that they’re both acceptable languages, and in your post you also implied that PHP is easier to write and listed off other perceived advantages. It doesn’t matter anwyay since OP asked why PHP was a bad language and which other language he should learn instead. Telling him to “do whatever” isn’t answering his question and is flat-out pointless to mention.

Read full topic

I just read this article that SilentCj commented http://www.leonardteo.com/2012/07/ruby-on-rails-vs-php-the-good-the-bad/ they say that RoR is such a better, and more powerful language but is very hard to learn for new programmers.

Or

item.title: PHP Alternative?
item.dc:creator: @RSCShadow RSCShadow
item.description:
@RSCShadow wrote:

[quote=“The Web Guy, post:30, topic:543612”][quote author=robonick8 link=topic=662493.msg4428333#msg4428333 date=1401925033]
Well most of you are saying stop with PHP and go with RoR, but then The Web Guy who I know happens to be a great web dev is telling me to stick with PHP

I just read this article that SilentCj commented http://www.leonardteo.com/2012/07/ruby-on-rails-vs-php-the-good-the-bad/ they say that RoR is such a better, and more powerful language but is very hard to learn for new programmers.

I am a quite a new programmer so Im not sure if I should take the Long easy route which is learning PHP then maybe another then go learn RoR

Or

Go the short route which is just starting on RoR and forgetting PHP.
[/quote]

Do what you think is best, they both seem to do similar things. If I didn’t know either, and had no programming knowledge, and I looked at code excerpts from RoR and PHP, I would look at Ruby… What the hell does this mean… I’d look at PHP… I’d probably still say “what the hell does this mean?” but it would be a little more understandable. Some what a personal preference. I don’t know what the community base for RoR is like, but I know PHP is common and has a strong community of people ready to help, and lots of tutorials.[/quote]You have to learn the language first before you try and learn how to use frameworks. RoR also isn’t the only framework available for Ruby. If you look at frameworks like Sinatra, they’re super easy to understand and don’t come with a lot of bloat.

https://github.com/sinatra/sinatra/

Just because one language looks slightly easier to read at first glance than another doesn’t mean it’s more worthwhile to learn than the objectively superior option. A good chunk of the PHP tutorials are poorly written and encourage exploitable programs on top of that.

Read full topic

Some what a personal preference. I don’t know what the community base for RoR is like, but I know PHP is common and has a strong community of people ready to help, and lots of tutorials.

item.title: PHP Alternative?
item.dc:creator: @HcoJustin HcoJustin
item.description:
@HcoJustin wrote:

The problem with rails is it’s not designed for doing a sight like simple calculator. It was designed to be used in larger sites that can benefit from a MVC design.

You also shouldn’t be using post/get for this, simple JavaScript would work just fine.

Read full topic

item.title: PHP Alternative?
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

[quote=“sinisoul, post:22, topic:543612”]Well, probably have a controller for the calculator:

class CalculatorController
end

Then, you obviously need a method for the operation. Fuck I’ll just write it all out.

Note: Probably not 100% correct I iz not a RoR master

class CalculatorController
  def operation
    i = params['firstVar'].to_i.send(params['operator'], params['secondVar'].to_i)
  end

  private
    def calculator_params
      params.require('calculator').allow('firstVar').allow('secondVar).allow('operator'')  # Sanitize operator to only be '+', '-', '/', '*'
    end
end

Something like that. With more sanitation.[/quote]

Hmm… Def, params.require, allow, end, private, that all means nothing to me. o.O

Read full topic

item.title: PHP Alternative?
item.dc:creator: @sinisoul sini
item.description:
@sinisoul wrote:

Well, probably have a controller for the calculator:

class CalculatorController
end

Then, you obviously need a method for the operation. Fuck I’ll just write it all out.

Note: Probably not 100% correct I iz not a RoR master

class CalculatorController
  def operation
    i = params['firstVar'].to_i.send(params['operator'], params['secondVar'].to_i)
  end

  private
    def calculator_params
      params.require('calculator').allow('firstVar').allow('secondVar).allow('operator'')  # Sanitize operator to only be '+', '-', '/', '*'
    end
end

Something like that. With more sanitation. Probably a way to filter which method is called by the parameters, but I’m not guru enough to do that. So you COULD have a method for addition, subtraction, etc

Read full topic

item.title: PHP Alternative?
item.dc:creator: @The_Web_Guy The Web Guy
item.description:
@The_Web_Guy wrote:

I know absolutely nothing about Ruby, so one of you who do, please contribute. Give me a code example on how you would build a calculator with basic functions. My method with PHP…

[code]<?php
if($_SERVER[‘REQUEST_METHOD’] == ‘POST’) {
$firstVar = $_POST[‘firstVar’];
$operator = $_POST[‘operator’];
$secondVar = $_POST[‘secondVar’];
$sum = 0;
if($operator = ‘add’) {
$sum = $firstVar+$secondVar;
} else if ($operator = ‘sub’) {
$sum = $firstVar-$secondVar;
} else if ($operator = ‘mul’) {
$sum = $firstVar*$secondVar;
} else if ($operator = ‘div’) {
$sum = $firstVar/$secondVar;
}
header(‘Location: calculator.php?sum=’.$sum.’’);
}
?>

+ - * / = <?php if(isset($_GET['sum'])) { echo $_GET['sum']; } ?> [/code]

Can someone show me how it outcomes in Ruby? I’m honestly interested, if it’s worth while, then I’d try a switch. This is how the front-end looks…

Before…

After…

Took about three minutes to make.

Read full topic

item.title: PHP Alternative?
item.dc:creator: @lothy Lothy
item.description:
@lothy wrote:

Django is quite popular. It uses python.

You’ve always got your java stack as well, and if you want to use proprietary software then there’s the Microsoft stack (IIS using ASP.NET, C#, SQL Server).

Read full topic
